20110125230333.000|20110125230335.000|TR0|So what does it take to put together a 
20110125230335.000|20110125230337.000|TR0|State of the Union address?
20110125230337.000|20110125230340.000|TR0|
20110125230340.000|20110125230342.000|TR0|Senior presidential adviser David Axelrod 
20110125230342.000|20110125230344.000|TR0|says because it's so all-encompassing, 
20110125230344.000|20110125230346.000|TR0|it's a very difficult speech to write.  
20110125230346.000|20110125230349.000|TR0|That task falls mainly to the chief White 
20110125230349.000|20110125230351.000|TR0|House speechwriter, Jon Favreau.  In a 
20110125230351.000|20110125230353.000|TR0|behind the scenes video released by the 
20110125230353.000|20110125230355.000|TR0|White House, Favreau says he and the 
20110125230355.000|20110125230357.000|TR0|president worked together to craft the 
20110125230357.000|20110125230400.000|TR0|finished product. Listen to this.
20110125230400.000|20110125230402.000|TR0|
20110125230402.000|20110125230404.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
20110125230404.000|20110125230406.000|TR0|
20110125230406.000|20110125230409.000|TR0|JON FAVREAU, WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER:  
20110125230409.000|20110125230411.000|TR0|After we got back from Thanksgiving, we 
20110125230411.000|20110125230413.000|TR0|just started a whole bunch of policy 
20110125230413.000|20110125230415.000|TR0|meetings.  They involved just about 
20110125230415.000|20110125230417.000|TR0|everyone in every department, every agency 
20110125230417.000|20110125230420.000|TR0|in the White House.  Years ago, 
20110125230420.000|20110125230422.000|TR0|speechwriters and presidents probably had 
20110125230422.000|20110125230424.000|TR0|it a little easier because all you had to 
20110125230424.000|20110125230426.000|TR0|do was deliver a written version of the 
20110125230426.000|20110125230429.000|TR0|State of the Union to Congress.
20110125230429.000|20110125230431.000|TR0|
20110125230431.000|20110125230433.000|TR0|Usually, the way it's worked is I will 
20110125230433.000|20110125230435.000|TR0|write a little.  I will send it to the 
20110125230435.000|20110125230437.000|TR0|president.  He will write.  He will sent 
20110125230437.000|20110125230440.000|TR0|notes back to me.  And then we will just 
20110125230440.000|20110125230442.000|TR0|go back and forth with each other for 
20110125230442.000|20110125230444.000|TR0|pretty much the entire month of January.
20110125230444.000|20110125230446.000|TR0|
20110125230446.000|20110125230449.000|TR0|(END VIDEO CLIP)

20110125230517.000|20110125230520.000|TR0|difference?
20110125230520.000|20110125230522.000|TR0|
20110125230522.000|20110125230524.000|TR0|PAUL BEGALA, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST:  Oh, I 
20110125230524.000|20110125230526.000|TR0|think they make a tremendous difference.  
20110125230526.000|20110125230529.000|TR0|It actually rarely makes a difference in 
20110125230529.000|20110125230531.000|TR0|the polls, but I have to say it did for 
20110125230531.000|20110125230533.000|TR0|President Clinton on more than one 
20110125230533.000|20110125230535.000|TR0|occasion.       And here's why.  It's the 
20110125230535.000|20110125230537.000|TR0|State of the Union address and then the 
20110125230537.000|20110125230540.000|TR0|budget.  It comes together.  And it should 
20110125230540.000|20110125230542.000|TR0|be seen as one seamless process.  Here are 
20110125230542.000|20110125230544.000|TR0|his priorities and then here are his 
20110125230544.000|20110125230546.000|TR0|specific spending accounts.  And that 
20110125230546.000|20110125230548.000|TR0|tells the country what his strategic 
20110125230548.000|20110125230551.000|TR0|vision is for the country.
20110125230551.000|20110125230553.000|TR0|
20110125230553.000|20110125230555.000|TR0|It's incredibly important.  We would start 
20110125230555.000|20110125230557.000|TR0|working on it in the Clinton White House 
20110125230557.000|20110125230600.000|TR0|in June, in July.  In other words six 
20110125230600.000|20110125230602.000|TR0|months of the year, we had people working 
20110125230602.000|20110125230604.000|TR0|on the State of the Union address, because 
20110125230604.000|20110125230606.000|TR0|it was the most important policy proposals 
20110125230606.000|20110125230608.000|TR0|of the year.  And also it was a chance to 
20110125230608.000|20110125230611.000|TR0|try to put a little bit of vision on it.
20110125230611.000|20110125230613.000|TR0|
20110125230613.000|20110125230615.000|TR0|I have to say, if it was me, I would try

20110125230755.000|20110125230757.000|TR0|
20110125230757.000|20110125230800.000|TR0|BEGALA:  I do.  It was September of 1993, 
20110125230800.000|20110125230802.000|TR0|if memories serves, Wolf.  It was actually 
20110125230802.000|20110125230804.000|TR0|his health care speech, not a State of the 
20110125230804.000|20110125230806.000|TR0|Union address, but the same format.  He's 
20110125230806.000|20110125230808.000|TR0|standing there at the rostrum.
20110125230808.000|20110125230811.000|TR0|
20110125230811.000|20110125230813.000|TR0|You see the video here.  And he looks up 
20110125230813.000|20110125230815.000|TR0|to begin his speech, and it's the economic 
20110125230815.000|20110125230817.000|TR0|speech from seven or eight months ago.  
20110125230817.000|20110125230819.000|TR0|And it was a catastrophe.  We had loaded 
20110125230819.000|20110125230822.000|TR0|-- I was one of the aides who goofed.  We 
20110125230822.000|20110125230824.000|TR0|had loaded the wrong speech in the 
20110125230824.000|20110125230826.000|TR0|teleprompter accidentally.
20110125230826.000|20110125230828.000|TR0|
20110125230828.000|20110125230831.000|TR0|And what really had happened was the 
20110125230831.000|20110125230833.000|TR0|technicians had loaded the economic speech 
20110125230833.000|20110125230835.000|TR0|in there, because we were so late 
20110125230835.000|20110125230837.000|TR0|delivering the health care speech to them. 
20110125230837.000|20110125230839.000|TR0| They had to had something to put up on 
20110125230839.000|20110125230842.000|TR0|those plates to make sure that they were 
20110125230842.000|20110125230844.000|TR0|working.  And so by the time President 
20110125230844.000|20110125230846.000|TR0|Clinton got there, he's looking at those 
20110125230846.000|20110125230848.000|TR0|plates and he's saying, holy smokes, 
20110125230848.000|20110125230851.000|TR0|that's my economic speech.
20110125230851.000|20110125230853.000|TR0|
20110125230853.000|20110125230855.000|TR0|And so he had to speak on health care to 
20110125230855.000|20110125230857.000|TR0|the Congress and the country and the world 
20110125230857.000|20110125230859.000|TR0|live with no notes for nine-and-a-half 
20110125230859.000|20110125230902.000|TR0|minutes, because his genius adviser, me, 
20110125230902.000|20110125230904.000|TR0|had taken his glasses away because they 
20110125230904.000|20110125230906.000|TR0|bulked out his pocket and he looked hefty 
20110125230906.000|20110125230908.000|TR0|enough as it was, frankly.
20110125230908.000|20110125230911.000|TR0|
20110125230911.000|20110125230913.000|TR0|And so one of the worst moments of my 
20110125230913.000|20110125230915.000|TR0|life, I have to say one of the best of 
20110125230915.000|20110125230917.000|TR0|President Clinton's.  I later asked him 
20110125230917.000|20110125230919.000|TR0|what it felt like to stand there and have 
20110125230919.000|20110125230922.000|TR0|to speak about the most complex domestic 
20110125230922.000|20110125230924.000|TR0|policy issue without any notes for 
20110125230924.000|20110125230926.000|TR0|nine-and-a-half minutes.  He said, well, I 
20110125230926.000|20110125230928.000|TR0|looked up and I said a little prayer, and 
20110125230928.000|20110125230931.000|TR0|I said well, God, I guess you're testing 
20110125230931.000|20110125230933.000|TR0|me.  OK.  Here goes.
20110125230933.000|20110125230935.000|TR0|
20110125230935.000|20110125230937.000|TR0|And that's why the kind of self-confidence 
20110125230937.000|20110125230939.000|TR0|you want in your president.
20110125230939.000|20110125230942.000|TR0|
20110125230942.000|20110125230944.000|TR0|BLITZER:  That's why a president or an 
20110125230944.000|20110125230946.000|TR0|anchor or anyone else reading a 
20110125230946.000|20110125230948.000|TR0|teleprompter, Mary, should always have a 
20110125230948.000|20110125230951.000|TR0|hard copy in front of him or her, and not 
20110125230951.000|20110125230953.000|TR0|simply rely on that teleprompter, because, 
20110125230953.000|20110125230955.000|TR0|you know what, people make mistakes, 
20110125230955.000|20110125230957.000|TR0|teleprompters can go bad or whatever.
20110125230957.000|20110125230959.000|TR0|
20110125230959.000|20110125231002.000|TR0|But that's a lesson -- I hope the 
20110125231002.000|20110125231004.000|TR0|president when he shows up tonight has a 
20110125231004.000|20110125231006.000|TR0|hard copy of his speech with him, that 
20110125231006.000|20110125231008.000|TR0|Paul Ryan had a hard copy, Michele 
20110125231008.000|20110125231011.000|TR0|Bachmann has a hard copy, all the anchors

20110125231317.000|20110125231319.000|TR0|JACK CAFFERTY, CNN ANCHOR:  It turns out, 
20110125231319.000|20110125231322.000|TR0|Wolf, that you can add politics to the 
20110125231322.000|20110125231324.000|TR0|list of things that women do better than 
20110125231324.000|20110125231326.000|TR0|men.  And, by the way, that's a long list.
20110125231326.000|20110125231328.000|TR0|
20110125231328.000|20110125231330.000|TR0|The Daily Beast reports on a new study 
20110125231330.000|20110125231333.000|TR0|that shows female politicians are among 
20110125231333.000|20110125231335.000|TR0|the most productive and persuasive ones in 
20110125231335.000|20110125231337.000|TR0|the country.
20110125231337.000|20110125231339.000|TR0|
20110125231339.000|20110125231341.000|TR0|The research in "The American Journal of 
20110125231341.000|20110125231344.000|TR0|Political Science" is the first to compare 
20110125231344.000|20110125231346.000|TR0|the performance of male and female 
20110125231346.000|20110125231348.000|TR0|politicians. And it shows women do a 
20110125231348.000|20110125231350.000|TR0|better job at both securing pork for their 
20110125231350.000|20110125231353.000|TR0|home districts and shaping policy.
20110125231353.000|20110125231355.000|TR0|
20110125231355.000|20110125231357.000|TR0|Between 1984 to 2004, women politicians 
20110125231357.000|20110125231359.000|TR0|won about $50 million per year more for 
20110125231359.000|20110125231401.000|TR0|their districts than men did.
20110125231401.000|20110125231404.000|TR0|
20110125231404.000|20110125231406.000|TR0|And, as for policy, women sponsored more 
20110125231406.000|20110125231408.000|TR0|bills, attracted more co-sponsors than 
20110125231408.000|20110125231410.000|TR0|their male counterparts.  The women 
20110125231410.000|20110125231413.000|TR0|politicians' bills also made it farther 
20110125231413.000|20110125231415.000|TR0|through the legislative process, got more 
20110125231415.000|20110125231417.000|TR0|media attention.
20110125231417.000|20110125231419.000|TR0|
20110125231419.000|20110125231421.000|TR0|The authors say that this is because women 
20110125231421.000|20110125231424.000|TR0|do a better job at -- quote -- 
20110125231424.000|20110125231426.000|TR0|"logrolling, agenda-setting, coalition 
20110125231426.000|20110125231428.000|TR0|building and other deal-making activities" 
20110125231428.000|20110125231430.000|TR0|-- unquote.
20110125231430.000|20110125231433.000|TR0|
20110125231433.000|20110125231435.000|TR0|They suggest women make better politicians 
20110125231435.000|20110125231437.000|TR0|because they have to. Consider that women 
20110125231437.000|20110125231439.000|TR0|hold less than one in five of all national 
20110125231439.000|20110125231441.000|TR0|elected offices, so the ones who make it 
20110125231441.000|20110125231444.000|TR0|to Washington, they better be pretty good.
20110125231444.000|20110125231446.000|TR0|
20110125231446.000|20110125231448.000|TR0|The study concludes that in order to 
20110125231448.000|20110125231450.000|TR0|overcome any bias against women in 
20110125231450.000|20110125231453.000|TR0|leadership roles, these female politicians

20110125231457.000|20110125231459.000|TR0|

20110125231804.000|20110125231806.000|TR0|
20110125231806.000|20110125231808.000|TR0|Look, what does everybody talk about?  The 
20110125231808.000|20110125231810.000|TR0|economy.  What in the economy?  It is the 
20110125231810.000|20110125231812.000|TR0|unemployment rate, 9.4 percent.  But it's 
20110125231812.000|20110125231815.000|TR0|not the same thing across the country.  
20110125231815.000|20110125231817.000|TR0|Let me explain to you.  We have taken this 
20110125231817.000|20110125231819.000|TR0|map and we have taken states where the 
20110125231819.000|20110125231821.000|TR0|unemployment rate is substantially lower 
20110125231821.000|20110125231824.000|TR0|than the 9.4 percent, a difference of 1.5 
20110125231824.000|20110125231826.000|TR0|percent.
20110125231826.000|20110125231828.000|TR0|
20110125231828.000|20110125231830.000|TR0|Those are the states in green.  The states 
20110125231830.000|20110125231832.000|TR0|in red, for instance, like Michigan right 
20110125231832.000|20110125231835.000|TR0|here, are a point-and-a-half or a 
20110125231835.000|20110125231837.000|TR0|percentage-and- a-half higher than the 
20110125231837.000|20110125231839.000|TR0|national average.  So, here's the issue -- 
20110125231839.000|20110125231841.000|TR0|9.4 percent is the national average.  
20110125231841.000|20110125231844.000|TR0|These states like Michigan have 
20110125231844.000|20110125231846.000|TR0|unemployment rates higher than that.
20110125231846.000|20110125231848.000|TR0|
20110125231848.000|20110125231850.000|TR0|Why?  Because typically they are 
20110125231850.000|20110125231852.000|TR0|manufacturing states.  And we have seen a 
20110125231852.000|20110125231855.000|TR0|big decline in manufacturing.  Or take a 
20110125231855.000|20110125231857.000|TR0|look at Florida below me.  Take a look at 
20110125231857.000|20110125231859.000|TR0|California and Nevada over here.  These 
20110125231859.000|20110125231901.000|TR0|are states where we had a development 
20110125231901.000|20110125231904.000|TR0|boom.  Construction jobs have been lost.  
20110125231904.000|20110125231906.000|TR0|Other service jobs have been lost.
20110125231906.000|20110125231908.000|TR0|
20110125231908.000|20110125231910.000|TR0|Look at the states in green, though right 
20110125231910.000|20110125231912.000|TR0|down the middle of the country, the 
20110125231912.000|20110125231915.000|TR0|Mountain states.  Texas sort of just moved 
20110125231915.000|20110125231917.000|TR0|into the gray category.  Everything that's 
20110125231917.000|20110125231919.000|TR0|gray or black is around the same as the 
20110125231919.000|20110125231921.000|TR0|national average.  These are states that 
20110125231921.000|20110125231923.000|TR0|are doing well.  They have got more 
20110125231923.000|20110125231926.000|TR0|diversified economies depending on 
20110125231926.000|20110125231928.000|TR0|education, jobs, medical jobs, health care 
20110125231928.000|20110125231930.000|TR0|jobs, oil services, transportation.
20110125231930.000|20110125231932.000|TR0|
20110125231932.000|20110125231935.000|TR0|There are lots of areas -- accounting.  
20110125231935.000|20110125231937.000|TR0|There are lots of areas in the country 
20110125231937.000|20110125231939.000|TR0|that are growing.  So the 9.4 percent, 
20110125231939.000|20110125231941.000|TR0|which you're going to hear the president's 
20110125231941.000|20110125231943.000|TR0|critics talk a lot about, is not a 
20110125231943.000|20110125231946.000|TR0|national problem.  There are regions in 
20110125231946.000|20110125231948.000|TR0|this country that are doing substantially 
20110125231948.000|20110125231950.000|TR0|better.  So if you're looking for a job, 
20110125231950.000|20110125231952.000|TR0|you want to combine some of these green 
20110125231952.000|20110125231955.000|TR0|states with states that in 2010 added job 
20110125231955.000|20110125231957.000|TR0|as opposed to lost jobs, and there is 
20110125231957.000|20110125231959.000|TR0|actually promise in this economy.
20110125231959.000|20110125232001.000|TR0|
20110125232001.000|20110125232003.000|TR0|We have turned a bit of a corner here.  
20110125232003.000|20110125232006.000|TR0|The problem that continues for the 
20110125232006.000|20110125232008.000|TR0|president, Wolf, are the long-term 
20110125232008.000|20110125232010.000|TR0|unemployed, the 15 million unemployed, and 
20110125232010.000|20110125232012.000|TR0|the five million or so what we call 99ers. 
20110125232012.000|20110125232015.000|TR0|You know that expression.  These are 
20110125232015.000|20110125232017.000|TR0|people who have unemployed for more than 
20110125232017.000|20110125232019.000|TR0|99 weeks.  They have run out of state

20110125233958.000|20110125234000.000|TR0|
20110125234000.000|20110125234003.000|TR0|BLITZER:  There's going to be a lot of 
20110125234003.000|20110125234005.000|TR0|emphasis, though, Gloria, on investments.
20110125234005.000|20110125234007.000|TR0|
20110125234007.000|20110125234009.000|TR0|GLORIA BORGER, CNN POLITICAL ANALYST:  
20110125234009.000|20110125234012.000|TR0|Sure.
20110125234012.000|20110125234014.000|TR0|
20110125234014.000|20110125234016.000|TR0|BLITZER:  And Republicans say that's just 
20110125234016.000|20110125234018.000|TR0|-- that's just a euphemism for more 
20110125234018.000|20110125234020.000|TR0|government spending.
20110125234020.000|20110125234023.000|TR0|
20110125234023.000|20110125234025.000|TR0|BORGER:  Right.  You know, the Democrats 
20110125234025.000|20110125234027.000|TR0|are saying you've got to invest to grow.
